key_insight: Psychometric test batteries can reliably measure personality-like traits in large, instruction-tuned LLMs, and these measured profiles can be deliberately mimicked to alter downstream behavior.
problem_solved: Lack of a rigorous, validated framework to quantify and shape consistent personality-like traits in LLMs for evaluation, benchmarking, and controlled behavior shaping.
method: Adapt established psychometric instruments (e.g., Big Five-style questionnaires) into prompts and test batteries for LLMs.
Quantitatively validate measurements via reliability and replication analyses across model families and prompting conditions.
Demonstrate shaping by conditioning or fine-tuning models to reproduce specific personality profiles and measuring downstream task effects.
impact: Provides a reproducible evaluation and intervention toolkit for practitioners to benchmark, customize, and audit model behavioral tendencies—useful for alignment, personalization, and safety testing.
visual_elements: Pipeline flowchart: psychometric test → scoring & reliability analysis → personality-conditioned generation
Radar chart (Big Five) comparing ground-truth/target profiles and model-measured profiles
Heatmap or bar chart of reliability/replicability metrics across model sizes and tuning types
Before/after example dialog snippet illustrating behavior change when a model is shaped to a target profile
paper_title: A psychometric framework for evaluating and shaping personality traits in large language models
paper_authors: Gregory Serapio-García, Mustafa Safdari, Clément Crepy, Luning Sun, Stephen Fitz
